summary:
High-Level Report: Community 21 Overview

Community 21 represents a self-contained, triadic framework of core machine-learning concerns, where each element is equally connected to the other two. It highlights a balanced methodology that gives equal weight to algorithm design, data preparation, and system implementation.

Key Insights  
• Triad of Focus Areas – Model-centric, Data-centric, and Engineering-centric methods form the three foundational pillars.  
• Full Interconnectivity – Every topic directly links to the other two, underscoring an integrated approach.  
• Balanced Emphasis – No single area dominates; model development, data quality, and deployment engineering share equal importance.  
• Expanded Methodological Scope – By naming “Engineering-centric” alongside traditional model and data perspectives, the community broadens its recognition of where innovation and practical challenges arise.  
• Neutral Position – There are no external claims, endorsements, or legal considerations associated with these entities.

This structure suggests that future research, tooling, and best practices borne from Community 21 will need to address all three dimensions in concert to achieve robust, scalable, and data-driven machine-learning systems.
